titles.title: CarD-T: LLM Automated Literature Review for the Nomination & Analysis of Potential Human Carcinogens

dates.dateInformation: Poster presented at AACR Annual Meeting 2025

descriptions.description: Carcinogenic Determination via Transformers (CarD-T) is an automated pipeline that combines transformer-based machine learning with probabilistic analysis to identify potential carcinogens from biomedical literature. Only 479 carcinogenic entities are officially recognized as carcinogens across regulatory databases (IARC, NTP, EPA, ECHA, and OSHA). Regulatory agencies rely on manual curation and are burdened by exponential growth of biomedical literature. CarD-T addresses these limitations by using a Named Entity Recognition (NER) ELECTRA LLM trained on carcinogen-specific contexts from PubMed literature to automate literature review of carcinogen curation with probabilistic analysis of likely carcinogenicity. The framework processes accumulating scientific publications, applies a trained NER model to extract potential carcinogenic entities, and uses Probabilistic Carcinogen Denomination (PCarD) to analyze temporal trends in evidence shifts. This approach enables classification of candidates through Bayesian temporal analysis, overcoming limitations of traditional manual literature review methods.

CarD-T uses a Named Entity Recognition (NER) ELECTRA LLM trained on carcinogen-specific contexts from PubMed literature. Training data consisted of abstracts referencing IARC Group 1 and Group 2A carcinogens. A novel AI-hybridized Context-Derived TF-IDF approach was implemented for noise reduction and synonym consolidation, converting implicating publications into evidence counts. The PCarD module applies Bayesian Negative Binomial Regression to analyze temporal evidence shifts, evaluating potential carcinogens based on changing evidence discourse with respect to time. The framework is designed to run on consumer hardware, democratizing carcinogen surveillance capabilities previously limited to specialized institutions.

Key findings include: CarD-T identifies 100% of IARC carcinogens with just 60% training data; approximately 1,600 potential new carcinogens discovered across diverse categories; superior recall (0.85 vs 0.76) with comparable precision (0.89 vs 0.90) compared to GPT-4; 554 entities with both supporting and opposing evidence analyzed; framework runs on standard hardware in approximately 6 hours; novel nominees include COVID-19, microplastics, and schizophrenia; resolves 76 disputed entities via temporal evidence modeling. The research documented a fundamental 25-year paradigm shift from chemical to biological and environmental carcinogenesis, with chemical compounds decreasing from 45% to 35%, biological agents increasing from 20% to 28%, and environmental factors increasing from 12% to 18%.
Presented at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting 2025, held April 25-30, 2025, at McCormick Place Convention Center, Chicago, Illinois. Poster number: LB108.

ast.title: CarD-T: LLM Automated Literature Review for the Nomination & Analysis of Potential Human Carcinogens
ast.introduction: Only 479 carcinogenic entities are officially recognized as carcinogens across regulatory databases including IARC, NTP, EPA, ECHA, and OSHA. Regulatory agencies rely on manual curation and are burdened by exponential growth of biomedical literature. CarD-T is an LLM framework developed to automate literature review of carcinogen curation with probabilistic analysis of likely carcinogenicity. The framework addresses the challenge that current systems, like those run by the International Agency for Research on Cancer and the National Toxicology Program, face challenges due to manual vetting and disparities in carcinogen classification spurred by the volume of emerging data.
ast.methods: CarD-T uses a Named Entity Recognition (NER) ELECTRA LLM trained on carcinogen-specific contexts from PubMed literature. The novelty of an NER approach over other LLM methods lies in the ability to index identified carcinogens to source documents, circumventing hallucinations. Training data consisted of abstracts referencing IARC Group 1 and Group 2A carcinogens. A novel AI-hybridized Context-Derived TF-IDF approach was implemented for noise reduction and synonym consolidation, converting implicating publications into evidence counts. The PCarD module applies Bayesian Negative Binomial Regression to analyze temporal evidence shifts, evaluating potential carcinogens based on changing evidence discourse with respect to time.
ast.results: CarD-T identifies 100% of IARC carcinogens with just 60% training data. Approximately 1,600 potential new carcinogens were discovered across diverse categories. The framework achieves superior recall (0.85 vs 0.76) with comparable precision (0.89 vs 0.90) compared to GPT-4. A total of 554 entities with both supporting and opposing evidence were analyzed. The framework runs on standard hardware in approximately 6 hours. Novel nominees include COVID-19, microplastics, and schizophrenia. The system resolved 76 disputed entities via temporal evidence modeling. Analysis revealed a fundamental 25-year research paradigm shift from chemical to biological and environmental carcinogenesis, with chemical compounds decreasing from 45% to 35%, biological agents increasing from 20% to 28%, and environmental factors increasing from 12% to 18%.
ast.conclusions: Successfully integrated transformer learning with Bayesian modeling to assess temporal shifts in scientific consensus on carcinogens. Documented fundamental 25-year research paradigm shift from chemical to biological and environmental carcinogenesis. Current regulatory frameworks (except IARC) remain focused on chemical mechanisms despite emerging evidence for diverse carcinogenic pathways. Temporal analysis provides critical context for evaluating contested entities where evidence conflicts or evolves over time. Open-source design on consumer hardware democratizes carcinogen surveillance capabilities previously limited to specialized institutions. Enables rapid response to emerging threats like COVID-19 by continuously monitoring scientific discourse in real-time. Creates new opportunities for proactive public health monitoring without commercial or computational barriers.
